place.desc:
白台寺 金至清 山西省，运城市， 新绛县 Băitáisì ZGWWDTJ, vol. 3 (xia), p.1099 126 – C 1,
(About 200 meters southwest of Gujiao village in Guangma town•Jin and Yuan Dynasties•Provincial Cultural Heritage Site) (untranslated CG) Also called Pŭhuàsì (普化寺). Called Băitáisì (white seat temple) because legend holds Buddha’s lotus throne to be white. According to stele inscription,had many restorations in the fourtheenth year of Tang Kaiyuan (726)、and between the Jin Dading and Mingchang years, further restored in the first year of Zhizheng (1355) and the sixth year of Ming Zhengde (1511). Increase in construction in Qing Dynasty. Occupancy area of 4,482 square meters. Facing south, 2 entrance courtyard design, axial buildings include a sāndīfăcánggé (三滴法藏阁)， shìjiādiàn (释迦殿)， and a hòudàdiàn (后大殿)， on either side there is an east shānmén (山门） and a west wing. Within complex interior is preserved a Tang dynasty pagoda, a Song dynasty jīngchuáng(经幢) stone pillar with Buddhist inscriptions, a Song cloud board from the third year of Xuanhe (1121) , and 18 colored/painted walls. Translated by Lydia Ohl; edited by Cole Garrett

白台寺 金至清 山西省，运城市， 新绛县 Băitáisì ZGWWDTJ, vol. 3 (xia), p.1099 126 – C 1-2 Shìjiādiàn (释迦殿) Jin Dynasty
Rebuilt in Jin Mingchang years (1190-1194). Stone podium, according to topography and building, front is 0.75 meters tall, back is 0.3 meters tall, front façade of 3 bays, depth of 6 rafters, single eave hip gable roof , main roof ridge、vertical ridge、berm ridge and temple ridge are made of carved brick. Under eave column top bracket set have 4 pūzuò(铺作) and a single xia ang, be careful of inter columnar bracket sets. Internal beam composition of 4 rafters that connect to back with 3 columns, overturned basin shaped column base. Be careful of central bay door, other bays have lattice windows. Hall interior Buddhist altar presents 12 portraits of Buddha, Sakyamuni Buddha in the center, both sides have an Ananda (阿难)、Mahākāśyapa（迦叶）、bodhisattva (菩萨), under two gables there are 6 arahats, horizontal back wall has a portrait of Weituo (韦陀)，later generations have already changed the shape, their original characteristics have been lost. Translated by Lydia Ohl; revised by Cole Garrett
